Line 70:   
Line 71:   WriteLiteral(@"
Line 72:   
Line 73:   <p>
Line 74:       This page describes structured logging, and how to use it with your JavaScript logs.
Line 75:   </p>
Line 76:   
Line 77:   <h2>About structured logging</h2>
Line 78:   <p>
Line 79:       When logging an event, often you not only want to log a string, but also the values of some variables, or even an entire object.
Line 80:       However, in most cases the log entries are stored as simple strings, such as in a text file or in a column in a relational database.
Line 81:   </p>
Line 82:   <p>
Line 83:       This leads to code like this:
Line 84:   </p>
Line 85:   <pre>log.Fatal(string.Format(""Something happened! x={0}, y={1}"", x, y))</pre>
Line 86:   <p>
Line 87:       This is fine until you want to search or order log entries based on those variable values. If you want to find all log entries
Line 88:       with x < 34, sorted descending by the values of y, you'll have to somehow parse your log entries.
Line 89:   </p>
Line 90:   <p>
Line 91:       Instead of destroying the structure of your log entries by converting them to strings, and then resurrecting that structure
Line 92:       by parsing them, why not leave the structure in place? This is where structured logging comes in.
Line 93:   </p>
Line 94:   <h3>Structured logging from your server side application</h3>
Line 95:   <p>
Line 96:       Whereas logging packages such as
Line 97:       <a");
Line 98:   
Line 99:   EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 400, 1154, true);

Line 152:  WriteLiteral(@">Serilog</a>

Line 155:  <p>
Line 156:      For example, Serilog allows you to write this C# code:
Line 157:  </p>
Line 158:  <pre>
Line 159:  var position = new { Latitude = 25, Longitude = 134 };
Line 160:  var elapsedMs = 34;

Line 217:  </p>
Line 218:  
Line 219:  <h3>Storing structured logs</h3>
Line 220:  <p>
Line 221:      How would you store a structured log? Text files are out, because you don't want to destructure log entries into flat text anymore.
Line 222:      Relational databases are not practicle, because you would have to define columns for each variable you would ever want to log.
Line 223:  </p>
Line 224:  <p>
Line 225:      However,
Line 226:      <a");
Line 227:  
Line 228:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2388, 367, true);
Line 229:  
Line 230:  BeginContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2755, 63, true);
Line 231:  
Line 232:  WriteLiteral(" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document-oriented_database\"");
Line 233:  
Line 234:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2755, 63, true);
Line 235:  
Line 236:  BeginContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2818, 16, true);
Line 237:  
Line 238:  WriteLiteral(" target=\"_blank\"");
Line 239:  
Line 240:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2818, 16, true);
Line 241:  
Line 242:  BeginContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2834, 314, true);
Line 243:  
Line 244:  WriteLiteral(@">NoSQL document databases</a> are ideal for this task.
Line 245:      Unlike relational databases, these allow you to store objects of any shape, without having to pre-define a schema.
Line 246:      However, they offer the same ability as relational databases to search and order objects based on their properties.
Line 247:  </p>
Line 248:  <p>
Line 249:      <a");
Line 250:  
Line 251:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 2834, 314, true);
Line 252:  
Line 253:  BeginContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 3148, 8, true);
Line 254:  
Line 255:  WriteLiteral(" href=\"\"");
Line 256:  
Line 257:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 3148, 8, true);
Line 258:  
Line 259:  BeginContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 3156, 16, true);
Line 260:  
Line 261:  WriteLiteral(" target=\"_blank\"");
Line 262:  
Line 263:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 3156, 16, true);
Line 264:  
Line 265:  BeginContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 3172, 413, true);
Line 266:  
Line 267:  WriteLiteral(@">MongoDB</a> is a popular document databases that is supported by Serilog.
Line 268:      In the remainder of this page you'll see how to use it to store your structured logs.
Line 269:  </p>
Line 270:  
Line 271:  <h2>Set up structured JavaScript logging</h2>
Line 272:  <p>
Line 273:      Now that you've seen what structured logging is, you'll see
Line 274:      how to use JSNLog and Serilog to log JavaScript events in a structured way in a server side MongoDB database
Line 275:      (<a");

Line 277:  EndContext("~/Views/Documentation/GetStartedLogging/StructuredLogging.cshtml", 3172, 413, true);
